rev.comment: Copy text from main article section, sorta trying to get this into summary style
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:   +
[[File:Oakland General Strike 2011-11-02.jpg|thumb|One of the marches to the Port of Oakland on Nov. 2, 2011]] Thousands of protesters gathered at Frank Ogawa Plaza to participate in rallies, marches, and teach-ins designed to empower citizens and to draw attention to economic inequity and corporate greed. <ref>{{cite news|title=California protesters shut down Oakland port|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15568057|accessdate=November 2, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=California protesters shut down Oakland port|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/02/occuply-oakland-general-strike-live|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|publisher=The Guardian News Blog}}</ref> The last general strike in the United States was in Oakland in 1946. Local unions expressed solidarity for the [[strike action|strike]] including Oakland's largest union, [[Service Employees International Union|Service Employees International Union]] Local 1021, Oakland Education Association, [[International Longshore and Warehouse Union|International Longshore and Warehouse Union]] Local 10, and [[United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America|United Brotherhood of Carpenters]]. While none of the unions were officially on strike, many urged their members to take a personal day, vacation day or to participate after work. <ref>{{cite news|last=Gee|first=Robyn|title=Teachers, Service Workers Support Oakland's Strike Without Striking|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/turnstyle/teachers-service-workers_b_1071604.html|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=November 2, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
While most of the day-time activities were peaceful, Oakland Police chief Howard Jordan reported that a small group of "anarchists" vandalized a [[Whole Foods]] storefront, and broke windows and [[ATM]]s of [[Bank of America]] and [[Wells Fargo]] banks in the afternoon. <ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland General Strike Shuts Down Port; Anarchists âBent On Creating Problemsâ|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/02/general-strike-protesters-shut-down-port-of-oakland/|accessdate=3 November 2011|publisher=CBS San Francisco|date=2 November 2011}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19246904 At least 4,000 are at the gates to the Port of Oakland]</ref> Many buildings were vandalized, including some businesses that displayed signs of support for the General Strike. After the incidents of vandalism, members of Occupy Oakland organized to guard local businesses, board up broken windows, and clean graffiti caused by the [[black bloc]] vandals. Oakland mayor Jean Quan described the vandals as "a small and isolated group" that "shouldn't mar the overall impact of the demonstration and the fact that people in the 99 percent movement demonstrated peacefully and, for the most part, were productive and very peaceful."<ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2011%2F11%2F03%2FBACM1LQ5FU.DTL]</ref>
  +   +
Thousands of protesters marched from Frank Ogawa Plaza to the [[Port of Oakland]], the fifth busiest port in the United States, in two separate groups leaving the plaza at 4:00 pm and 5:00 pm. The number of protesters marching to the port has not been confirmed. While police estimate 7,000 people marched, local organizers <ref>{{cite news|title=Video Report from Streets of Oakland: First General Strike in City Since 1946 Shuts Down Major Port|url=http://www.democracynow.org/seo/2011/11/3/video_report_from_streets_of_oakland|accessdate=November 6, 2011|publisher=Democracy Now|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref> and participants <ref>{{cite news|last=Abraham|first=Zennie|title=Occupy Oakland Strike Draws 100,000; Violence Caused By 100|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/11/03/occupy-oakland-strike-draws-100000-violence-caused-by-100/|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle - Blog}}</ref> put the number somewhere between 20,000 and 100,000. As protesters completely filled Middle Harbor Road, the main road leading to the port, all truck traffic entering or exiting the port was halted. Port operations were "effectively shut down" a couple hours later. <ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland throng closes down port|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/MN8Q1LPI1J.DTL|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|newspaper=The San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref> During the march a frustrated driver of a Mercedes struck two pedestrians who were taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The driver was questioned by BART police and released. <ref>{{cite news|last=Kuruvila|first=Matthai|title=Mercedes hits 2 Occupy Oakland protesters|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/BA5G1LQ06S.DTL|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
